description: From New Latin academia, from Ancient Greek Ἀκαδημία (Akadēmía); Doublet of academy. Academe (frequently capitalized) is a poetic name for the garden or grove near ancient Athens where Plato taught, supposedly named for its former owner, the hero Ἀκάδημος (Akademos; Ἑκάδημος, Hekademos).

entries.meaning: (historical) The name of the garden in Athens where the academics met. [from late 16th c.]
(poetic) An academy; a place of learning. [from late 16th c.]
(poetic) The scholarly life, environment, or community. [from mid 19th c.]
A senior member of the staff at an institution of higher learning; pedant. [from mid 20th c.]
